title: Son of Robert Mugabe arrested in South Africa on suspicion of attempted murder

originalTitle: US trade deficit swells in December as imports surge
title: America's Big Shopping Spree: What It Means!
content:
Hello, amazing friends all across Africa! It's your kid-friendly reporter, always ready to share exciting news from around the world. Today, we're going to talk about something that might sound a little grown-up, but it's really like a big shopping story! It's about America and how much they buy and sell with other countries. Are you ready? Let's go!

What is 'Trade'? Imagine a Giant Swap Meet!

Imagine you have a super cool toy car, but your friend has an amazing bouncy ball, and you both want to swap! That's a bit like 'trade' between countries. Countries 'trade' when they buy and sell things to each other. For example, maybe our country, South Africa, sells delicious fruits like mangoes to other countries. And maybe we buy cool electronics like cell phones from countries like China or Korea. This buying and selling is called 'trade'. It happens all the time!

America's Shopping List: Buying Lots of Things!

Now, let's talk about America, a big country far away. Just like you might go to the market with your parents to buy food, America also 'buys' things from other countries. When a country buys things from another country, we call those 'imports'. Imagine America buying lots and lots of cool toys, yummy snacks, fast cars, and shiny new phones from all over the world. They buy so many things! In December, which was at the end of last year, America bought even more things than usual from other countries. It was like they went on a giant shopping spree! Everyone in America was buying lots of goodies that came from other places. Did you know? Countries often trade because some places are better at making certain things! Like, some countries have special soil for growing coffee beans, while others have factories that are really good at building cars!

What Does 'Deficit' Mean? Like Spending More Pocket Money!

Here's a bit of a tricky word: 'deficit'. Don't worry, it's not too hard! Imagine your mom or dad gives you some pocket money, let's say 10 rands. If you spend 15 rands on sweets, you've spent more than you had, right? You have a 'deficit' of 5 rands. It means you spent more than you earned or had. Now, for countries, a 'trade deficit' means they bought more things from other countries (imports) than they sold to other countries (exports). So, in December, America bought way, way more things than it sold to other countries. Their 'trade deficit' got bigger, like spending way too much pocket money!

President Trump's Big Idea: Special Stickers!

At that time, America had a leader called President Trump. He wanted America to sell more things and buy fewer things from other countries. He wanted the buying and selling to be more equal. So, he had a big idea! He decided to put special 'stickers' on things that came from other countries. These 'stickers' weren't really stickers, but extra money people had to pay to buy things from other countries. These special extra payments are called 'tariffs'. Imagine if a toy car from another country usually cost 5 rands, but President Trump put a 2 rand 'tariff sticker' on it. Now, the toy car would cost 7 rands! He hoped that if things from other countries were more expensive, people in America would buy things made right there in America instead. Did you know? Some of the most traded items in the world include oil, cars, and computer parts! These things travel huge distances across oceans and lands to reach different countries.

What Happened with the Stickers?

President Trump put lots and lots of these 'sticker taxes' (tariffs) on things. He really wanted to make the 'deficit' smaller. But guess what? Even with all those extra 'sticker taxes', people in America still bought a lot of things from other countries! In December, America's shopping spree got even bigger, and their 'trade deficit' grew even more. It was like people really, really wanted those things from other countries, even if they cost a little more!

Why Does This Matter to You and Me?

When a country has a big 'trade deficit', it means they are spending a lot of money on things from other places. Sometimes, this can be a little bit worrying, just like if your family spends much more money than they earn. It means they might need to borrow money from other countries to pay for everything. But it also means that people in America have lots of choices for things to buy! They can choose from toys, clothes, and food made all over the world. And it shows how connected all our countries are – we all share and trade different things. Did you know? The Silk Road was a very famous ancient trade route that connected different parts of Asia, Europe, and Africa! People traded silk, spices, and many other goods along this long path many, many years ago. So, while President Trump hoped his 'sticker taxes' would make America buy less from other countries, it didn't quite work out that way in December. America kept on shopping! It reminds us that people sometimes really want what they want, even if it costs a little extra. And that's our big shopping story from America for today! Keep exploring and learning, my friends! See you next time!
summary: America bought many more things from other countries than it sold in December, making its 'trade deficit' bigger, even though President Trump tried to make foreign goods more expensive with special 'tariffs'.
whyMatters: This matters because when a country buys a lot more than it sells, it's like spending more money than you have, which can sometimes mean they need to borrow money from other countries, but it also means people have lots of different things to choose from!

originalTitle: The eerie similarities between Arsenal's 2007-8 collapse and now
title: The eerie similarities between Arsenal's 2007-8 collapse and now
content: Arsenal's disappointing 2-2 draw at Wolves on Wednesday has similarities to what happened to the Gunners 18 years ago.

originalTitle: Women's FA Cup revamp on hold after 'ridiculous idea' criticism
title: Women's FA Cup revamp on hold after 'ridiculous idea' criticism
content: Plans to change the format of the Women's FA Cup, which would have seen four sides seeded and pathways to Wembley mapped out from the last 32 onwards, will not be brought in next season.
